titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

body.p: I began an article for the Bishoprick, on the name "Protestant" which passed into the vocabulary of Christendom just 400 years ago.

I accompanied Chelmsford to Mainsforth Colliery, where he formally opened the Pit–head Baths, which had been erected by the Miners' Welfare Fund. We began by going through the building, & being shown the numerous arrangements for the man's convenience and comfort. Then we lunched in a tent very pleasantly. I sate between the Chairman, Mr. Dorman, of the firm Dorman Long & Co which owns the mine, and Mr Ben Turner, the new Minister for Mines â€“ a tubby little fat man with the expansive geniality & unctuous fervour of his professional mission–preacher. After lunch there was a meeting of the workmen, who attended in large numbers. I think there could hardly have been fewer than 2000 present. Chelmsford spoke, & then in succession Turner, Richardson, Robson, & Straker. The speakers seemed very [187] [symbol] anxious to pose as disinterested reformers of society & champions of the miners. They were evidently intrigued at seeing me there & worked in some references to my presence. After this function we returned to Auckland & had tea. Then we walked round the Park, deceiving the way with converse.
